summary: On August 21, 2017, the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants in a civil injunctive action brought by the court against them.  According to the SEC's complaint, filed in federal district court in Brooklyn, New York, on August 22, 2017 and unsealed on August 24, 2017 the defendants entered into an agreement in which they agreed to be permanently enjoined from violating the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder. The defendants also agreed to the issuance of a 10-day notice of quit and affidavits of service, which is a form of prohibited unfair collection practices.  The court entered the final judgment against the defendants without admitting or denying the allegations in the complaint, ordering the defendants to pay disgorgement of ill-gotten gains plus interest, penalties, and permanent injunctions.  In a parallel action, the United States Attorney's Office for New York today announced criminal charges against two defendants for their roles in the alleged misconduct.  On August 26, 2018, the court granted the defendants' motion for a preliminary injunction, entered an emergency consent judgment, and entered an order suspending the defendants from appearing or practicing before the court as to whether the defendants had violated the charged provisions of the federal securities laws. The court also granted the parties the right to a temporary restraining order and to appoint a receiver for the receiver of the receiver. The SEC's investigation was conducted by John Rymas of the New York Regional Office and supervised by Chedly C. Dumornay. The litigation will be led by Mr. and Ms. Mascianica. The case is being supervised by Sanjay Wadhwa.Â  The SEC appreciates the assistance of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in this matter, the New Jersey Department of Banking and Securities, and the Federal Office of Inspector General.
